weeklyReads.content1: Your baby is just starting to develop, and the neural tube is forming.
weeklyReads.content2: Take prenatal vitamins containing folic acid to support your baby's development.

weeklyReads: This week, your baby's heart begins to form, along with the neural tube.
Make sure to stay hydrated and eat nutritious foods to support your baby's growth.
Your baby's brain and spinal cord are beginning to take shape.
Avoid harmful substances such as alcohol, tobacco, and certain medications.
Your baby is now called an embryo and is developing rapidly.
Attend your first prenatal appointment to confirm your pregnancy and discuss prenatal care.
Your baby's heart is beginning to beat, and arm and leg buds are forming.
Start tracking your pregnancy symptoms and schedule regular prenatal check-ups.
Your baby's facial features are beginning to form, including eyes, ears, and nose.
Consider prenatal genetic testing if recommended by your healthcare provider.
Your baby's brain is growing rapidly, and facial features are becoming more defined.
Continue taking prenatal vitamins and eating a balanced diet rich in nutrients.
Your baby's fingers and toes are forming, and internal organs are developing.
Stay active with prenatal exercises such as walking, swimming, or yoga.
Your baby is now called a fetus and is becoming more active.
Start planning your maternity leave and preparing for your baby's arrival.
Your baby's vital organs are fully formed, and the skeleton is beginning to harden.
Discuss prenatal screening tests with your healthcare provider to assess your baby's health.
Your baby's facial features are more defined, and fingernails and toenails are forming.
Attend childbirth education classes to learn about labor, delivery, and newborn care.
Your baby's digestive system is developing, and vocal cords are forming.
Start thinking about baby names and creating a birth plan with your partner.
Your baby's kidneys are producing urine, and the liver is starting to function.
Enjoy regular physical activity such as prenatal yoga or swimming to stay healthy.
Your baby can now make facial expressions, and the hair on the head is growing.
Get plenty of rest and practice relaxation techniques to reduce stress.
Your baby's limbs are lengthening, and movements are becoming more coordinated.
Take time to connect with your baby by talking, singing, or playing music.
Your baby's eyes can now detect light, and ears are moving into their final position.
Attend prenatal appointments regularly and discuss any concerns with your healthcare provider.
Your baby's skeleton is hardening, and fingerprints are forming.
Start planning your baby shower and creating a registry for baby essentials.
Your baby's movements are becoming more noticeable, and you may feel kicks or flutters.
Begin thinking about breastfeeding and researching breastfeeding techniques.
Your baby's sensory organs are developing, including taste buds and smell receptors.
Continue taking childbirth classes and learning about pain management options for labor.
Your baby is halfway developed and may start to hiccup or suck their thumb.
Schedule a mid-pregnancy ultrasound to check your baby's growth and development.
Your baby's digestive system is maturing, and swallowing movements are increasing.
Discuss baby care and safety with your partner, including car seat installation and infant CPR.
Your baby's eyelids are now open, and eyebrows and eyelashes are starting to grow.
Plan a babymoon getaway with your partner to relax and enjoy time together before the baby arrives.
Your baby's skin is becoming more opaque, and blood vessels are visible through it.
Attend prenatal yoga or childbirth preparation classes to help prepare for labor and delivery.
Your baby's lungs are developing, and the nervous system is maturing.
Create a birth plan outlining your preferences for labor, delivery, and postpartum care.
Your baby's kicks and movements may become stronger and more frequent.
Start packing your hospital bag with essentials for labor, delivery, and postpartum recovery.
Your baby's lungs are producing surfactant, which helps with breathing after birth.
Discuss breastfeeding and newborn care with your healthcare provider or a lactation consultant.
Your baby's brain is developing rapidly, and the nervous system is becoming more complex.
Tour your hospital or birthing center to familiarize yourself with the facilities and procedures.
Your baby's eyes are opening, and the eyelids are less transparent.
Prepare for your baby's arrival by setting up the nursery and washing baby clothes.
Your baby's head is growing to accommodate the developing brain.
Take childbirth education classes to learn about pain management techniques and relaxation methods.
Your baby's lungs are maturing, and breathing movements are becoming more regular.
Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing and visualization to prepare for labor.
Your baby's bones are hardening, but the skull remains soft and flexible for birth.
Create a birth plan outlining your preferences for pain management, delivery positions, and newborn care.
Your baby's kicks and movements may feel stronger as they grow.
Schedule regular prenatal check-ups to monitor your baby's growth and well-being.
Your baby's immune system is developing, and they are gaining weight rapidly.
Stay hydrated and eat small, frequent meals to ease discomfort from indigestion and heartburn.
Your baby's skin is becoming smoother, and they are filling out with fat deposits.
Practice relaxation techniques such as prenatal yoga or meditation to reduce stress.
Your baby's head may engage in your pelvis in preparation for birth.
Pack your hospital bag with essentials for labor, delivery, and postpartum recovery.
Your baby's lungs are fully developed, and they are practicing breathing movements.
Attend childbirth education classes with your partner to prepare for labor and delivery.
Your baby is considered full term and may arrive at any time now.
Rest and relax as much as possible in preparation for labor and delivery.
Your baby's head may be engaged in your pelvis, ready for birth.
Stay in touch with your healthcare provider and report any signs of labor or complications.
Your baby's lungs are mature and ready for breathing on their own.
Rest and relax as much as possible in these final weeks of pregnancy.
Congratulations! Your baby is full term now and ready to be born.
Prepare for labor and delivery by packing your hospital bag and discussing your birth plan with your healthcare provider.
